page.title: 03CHADDESLEY CORBETT BUILDINGS
page.content: There are still many half timbered houses remaining in Chaddesley Corbett bordering what is believed to be an old Roman Road. The original wattle and daub has been replaced by brick in-filling and many timbers have been replaced by brick and painted over to disguise this fact. Many houses were destroyed by fire in the 17th century and rebuilt but the plots of land remain virtually the same. There are several Georgian Houses which includes a School House built in 1785 and a village Workhouse built in 1795. There are Charity Houses built in 1812 and an old schoolhouse built in 1809. Another school was built in 1848 and has been converted into flats and a Doctor's Surgery. The present school building was built in 1894 and extended in 1963. There are several Victorian Houses in the village.
